title: I'm afraid I've read better fanfictions with the same premise
text:
I'm not sure I can be convinced that this wasn't just a rather morbid fever dream. It's extremely difficult to see that Harry Potter grows up to loose almost every trait that ever made the character appealing to begin with, that he has in fact experienced negative character growth since the end of the series and that the status quo of his life has changed exactly none. As for the plot, I'm afraid I've read better fanfictions with the same premise. In fact, I mixed the details of this up with one of those fanfictions as soon as I was done reading it and when I sorted out the specifics I found all the better points belonged to the fanfiction. The fact that the function and rules of a time-turner had to be changed in order to accommodate this unfortunate mess does not endear any of the three authors to me. And, as has been stated in other reviews, this script is as similar to the Harry Potter series in tone as a carpenter ant is to a ballpoint pen.

I wouldn't even say I'm disappointed. More that I'm currently doing my best to Obliviate this from my memory, lest I actually allow the horrors committed against the characters to affect my fond memory of them.

However.... this book dragged on and on with mundane meaningless details that did not add to the story, but instead really took away from it. I felt like I waited forever to get to the end to find out what would happen and when she finally me up with old flame again it just lacked any substance or excitement, or anything. The final ending was good, but fee was it painful to get there :/

title: A superb story premise, but it muddles and fizzles quickly
text:
I showed the publisher's description of this mystery-adventure novel to my wife just after I ordered this book and she said, "That sounds like a really great one." I had harbored precisely the same thought so I was fully prepared to burn the midnight oil on this title. Unfortunately, my expectations did not come to fruition.

I'm going to give somewhat lengthy details of my critique because, if the author (Katherine Neville) happens across my mediocre rating of her book, she is entitled to hear EXACTLY WHY I did not care much for the work. Unfortunately, others might find this approach to be a little excessive but I take book reviews quite seriously (especially critical ones) and just saying, "I didn't like this book," would be entirely unfair to the author who worked so hard on it.

First, here's the story in a nutshell which I will convey with an eye to coherence rather than to just regurgitate the tale in the order in which it is yielded up by the author:

The chief heroine/protagonist, Alexandra Solarin, works in an exclusive Washington D.C. Basque specialty restaurant where she is being trained by the owner in the perfectionist art of preparing fine ethnic cuisine. Then she gets a strange invitation to attend her mother's birthday party at her mom's isolated Colorado home.

The mystery centers chiefly upon the pieces and playing board of an infamous chess set which is called The Montglane Service. This chess theme links to Alexandra in that she happens to be a chess genius and was well on the way to becoming a Master when her father who was accompanying her to a match in Russia was shot by an assassin.

In any event, the chess set of focus was devised in Baghdad by Islamic alchemist al-Jabir ibn Hayan in 765 C.E for the Caliph al-Mansur and was actually an encoded device for housing the mysteries of... well, what would be the most precious thing to any mortal human? And I'll leave the answer there. Perhaps a revealing excerpt from early in the story would also be expeditious here:

"...the secret of the marvelous chess set. It was a formula which, if solved, could do far more than create or destroy civilizations. It could transform both energy and matter and much, much else," (page 94).

In fact, there are numerous retrospectives between Hayan's day and 2003 (and at many chronological stops in between) which describe the happenings with the various chess pieces and the people who have been charged with their eternal safety and security, many of these folks losing their lives in the process. And who all is involved in this tangle? To name just a few: Charlemagne; Percy Shelly; Napoleon's mother; Tsar Alexander I; The U.S. Secret Service (sort of); The KGB; Talleyrand of France; The Piscataway Indians; Thoth of Egypt (obliquely); numerous ancient rulers and religious figures; and, many, many more. Sound confusing? It is. I began to think that Neville forgot to toss in Elvis and it was at about that point in the text that he popped up too!

The difficulties with this book are more general than they are specific. In the interest of clarity, I'll enumerate them:

1. This book has no core... no soul. I couldn't latch on to any of the principals and empathize with them for the literary ride. There are just way too many famous people and a similar number of exotic locations, all too excessive to make the story believable.

2. The endless pieces of this puzzle are not limited to the attempted theme of the Montglane [Chess] Service, the object which sets the stage for a mystery which is multi-dimensional a. in international settings, b. in time (from 765 C.E. to present day), and, c. in varying religious faiths as well. At just about the time that one believes that he or she has caught up with all the clues and dates, the author bombards us with yet another set of people, places, and times and after a few cycles of this, "the kitchen sink" comes to mind.

3. Alexandra and a number of her family members, peers, and associates are into interpreting codes and ciphers. Honestly, I found this aspect of the text to reek of juvenilia. At first I thought it to be a joke but after the fourth or fifth inanely written puzzle, in an adventure which purportedly takes itself seriously, I found it to be incongruous. While such caveats might have been appropriate in a tongue-and-cheek action thriller, perhaps in [[ASIN:B0014Z4OMU Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Ark (Special Edition)]] where there are some intentional moments of levity, these inconsistent brain-teasers took away from the seriousness of this particular story.

4. I never achieved a good mental vision of the characters in this book, Leda being the lone exception, (her description is quite nicely-rendered on page 149) -- this was a missed opportunity. While the principals' relationships to one another were fairly clear, (at least within the parameters of each chronological period), the general lack of character wallpaper generated an overall void which could have been so easily filled but wasn't.

5. At the outset of each chapter the author has inserted a quotation or two which purportedly punctuates the theme or object of the upcoming segment of text. This technique has, quite unfortunately, become much hackneyed and its employment in the face of this fact is quite unimaginative; when the practice is not used shrewdly and sparingly, the aggregate of the quotes simply begin to manifest as literary debris which is the case in this instance. To make matters even worse, one of these quotations, found on page 248, conveyed a tidbit by hedonist, astrologer, drug addict, and illuminist, Aleister Crowley, (1875-1947) a non-credible scoundrel of the First Water who was dubbed by the tabloid press of his day as `The Wickedest Man in the World,' and who claimed, among other titles, that of `Magus'. Even the readings at Crowley's cremation service (his own writings) were referred to in the press as 'A Black Mass,' an actuality which would have pleased the heinous mystic and alchemist on the highest level. Now, had the author also supplemented her book exclusively with quotations from people with like reputations and personalities such as Adolf Hitler, Charles Manson, Osama bin Laden, Reverend Jim Jones, and so on, I would have found Crowley's entry to be appropriate and not at all offensive. But her other quotations were chiefly from credible folks such as Alexander Dumas, W.B. Yeats, Charles Dickens and obliquely, the quotations come off (inadvertently, I'm sure) as if she were placing these other reputably notable people all in the same fraternity with Crowley. Somewhat in Neville's defense, Crowley's words were clearly employed resultant of his connections with the game of chess and with his extensive knowledge of codes and cyphers. But, to finalize this thought, I just felt that tossing the likes of Crowley in with Dumas and Company was an inattentive oversight and a mistake which should have been resisted. Perhaps this seems a small point but it is representative of gaffes which I seemed to encounter throughout the text.

6. I love books which insert a food/cooking interest. This one plugs into that appeal but we are hung out with no resolution at these opportune culinary moments. Alexandra speaks of the delectability of her Uncle's pancakes, among other items, but we're left to our own devices to ascertain WHY they were so great. We are given no secret ingredients, nor are the Uncle's special techniques revealed. Food is described throughout the book in complimentary terms and, fancying myself as an amateur chef, I really desired to latch on to this sub-interest... but I felt DEPRIVED to say the least! Even if the secret techniques would not work in actuality, as long as they had sounded plausible I would have been much gratified. I just wish that the author had developed this notion, having brought it in to begin with.

7. The technical errors, though not legion, are still of an individual magnitude as to really spoil this tale, even if everything else had been okay. In fact, someday, I am going to get rich by inventing the "novel writer's revolver" which features an UNNECESSARY safety and which, by its existence will bail book authors out of a mess which I once thought would eventually cease to occur in the literary world - but again, it has sadly popped up here. On page 425, one of the book's evil characters clicks the safety to the off position on a small pearl-handled revolver! This is an amateurish mistake and should NEVER happen. I emitted a great sigh of annoyance when it did. In an earlier part of the book, (page 148), Alexandra shuts down the burglar alarm in the restaurant where she works and when she ingresses the building, her friend, Leda, is already there. Does Leda's body mass somehow not set off burglar alarms? Again, these types of obvious errors in a book that is supposedly professionally published drag down the story. Another glitch I'm pretty well assured of caught my attention here. There is a reference to the "famous gingko bilbao trees" on page 275. Gingko Bilbao (I'm pretty certain on this) is the DRUG BRAND NAME for a non-pharmaceutical herbal curative which addresses men's weakening libido. The TREE from which it is extracted is actually the "Ginkgo" and for which the scientific name is "Ginkgo biloba" (so-called for its two-lobed leaves -- note the differences in the spelling of both words) So what this tells me is the publisher's fact-checker found it expedient to just track down the name of the herb extract, and not the tree itself. Perhaps the author had the Basque city of Bilbao, Spain in mind from her researching. I don't know but it was a sad hoot when I read that. Finally, there was a piece of dialogue (page 276) where one of the principals says, "Your Flat?" he snorted. "A campground has more amenities." I'm sorry but today's campgrounds (some specialty ones are also called RV Parks) are quite up to date in terms of technology and luxury, many offering everything from internet connections to Jacuzzis to one-stop shopping in the camp store. I got the feeling that the author had not "camped" in the past 30 years. I'm not discussing typos with all these items -- these are errors of fact, sloppy work on someone's part.

Now, I wish to emphasize that this book is NOT a piece of trash... I don't at all want to leave prospective readers with totally negative impressions here. In fact I believe that this book could be improved 100 percent given some high-quality editing and a little additional character development - the work holds every potential of rising to five stars. From my view, I hold the editor to be at least equally responsible as the author in this work's shortcomings, whatever they might be. Clearly, there will be people who will breeze through the book as it stands and they will enjoy it. It's just that, having read a number of works which embrace similarities of theme and literary profile, in addition to the hundreds of non-paralleling novels that I've read and many of which having struck me as terrific, that this one just did not make the grade.

Probably the best compliment that I can pay this novel is that it stands on its own even though it is, in fact, a sequel to a work which the author published 20 years ago. I didn't read that earlier entry ([[ASIN:0345419081 The Eight]]) but Katherine Neville did effect a fine job of making this book "whole" in that it's unnecessary to read the prequel to understand this later book. I should also say that I can appreciate the research that Neville must have performed in order to attempt to make the text as real as possible. This is a much more difficult task than simply writing a book solely from the knowledge which one accumulates over the years, penning a novel from that typically common, everyday information. And finally, the account is uniquely rendered in first person for the contemporary periods and in third person for the retrospectives - I've never encountered this before so perhaps this breaks some new ground in that realm, or at least it did for me. It's a well-established fact that writing a novel in first person is typically a challenge for even the best of authors.

However, this work does not break new ground as far as the particular theme goes - various aspects of the instant work have previously been explored in such books as "The Celestine Prophecy, (James Redfield); "The List of Seven," (Mark Frost); "Gospel," (Wilton Barnhardt); "River God," (Wilbur A. Smith); and in various Clive Cussler titles. In fact I would point out that, in addition to the previous contemporary titles and authors, there are two superb, older works which hold similarities of premise and/or in thematic approach: [[ASIN:0395957753 The Robe]] and, [[ASIN:0375757856 The Moonstone (Modern Library Classics)]], each of which were as solid and coherent as this one is perplexing and vague.

In summary, my expectations for this book had been pretty high in the beginning, having read the publisher's description but at the end, I finished the story only with considerable difficulty, chiefly embracing the distracting thought that the next book on my "to read" shelf would make up ground for this one. This novel is 435 pages in length and I found it neither compelling nor dynamic. It's just way too over-dramatized with too many tenuous (or non-existent) links. I also didn't care one bit for the bling-bling approach of "Lily's Gramp" going down in the North Tower of the World Trade Center on 9-11-01 as she was to meet him for an appointment. That idea has already been over-used and I found it as tasteless this time as I did in the very first instance that I encountered it.

I gave this book three stars instead of two as a consequence of my personal fever for historical fiction. In recommending it to others who do not necessarily share my devotion to the topic, I'm not sure that I could go three stars.

title: Biased
text:
I agree with a lot of the other reviews here; this book is more geared towards the childless than the childfree. There is a huge difference. The term childless applies to anyone who wants a child and cannot have one. The term childfree applies to anyone (straight, gay, or bisexual) who plans not to raise or bear children for a variety of reasons.

If you're looking for a childfree book, this isn't it.

title: Too much work for too little payoff
text:
While there’s a decent story in this book, a bit of a mystery, for me, it took far too much work to ferret it out. From the gimmicky chapter numbering which jumps all over the place, to the chapters consisting of a single page picture, there’s no timeline to grab onto, and I often felt myself scrambling to figure out exactly when things were happening. I found myself needing to keep a running summary of each chapter as I read. To me, this is work; not the enjoyment I expect from a book. I felt that the summary left much to be wanted in describing this book.

The book got off to very slow start. It took me three days to read the first 30 pages. After that point, things picked up and the book finally developed a rhythm I could get into. Still, I could never relax into this book because of how the timeline, or lack thereof, jumped around.

This book has many, many triggers for those who are sensitive. Here they are, if you're interested:
child abandonment, cancer, murder, drug use, death, snakes, rape, sadistic behavior

The book is dark and haunting. The characters are interesting, but I never felt that they were fully fleshed out. It seemed like the author had the desire to try to shock the reader in every way possible, but often without any real payoff for the reader.

The writing itself is quite good, at times almost poetic. Unfortunately, I think the book could have been much shorter. The author enjoyed showing all the lurid and horrible at the expense of character development and story pace. For instance, the chapters with Alvero and Flaca could have been cut in half, or even to a quarter of the length in this final version. It’s point is to show Alvero’s oddities and how they affected Penny, but I didn’t feel that it really worked all that well. It involved snakes, and I’m no fan of them, so that may have some influence on my opinion.

I did like Penny and Cale and some of the other characters, but not enough to really care what happens to them. I guess that was good because I didn’t come away feeling that I knew what happened to them. Too much was left unexplained.

I can’t say that this book is a favorite read of mine. It isn’t. I think it could have been, if the author hadn’t worked so hard to make it such a difficult, disagreeable read. To make it worse, I didn’t feel rewarded for all of my hard work in the end. It wasn’t a very satisfying conclusion in my eyes and left several threads flailing in the wind.

I doubt I’ll be recommending this book to anyone. It’s certainly not a book I intend to keep or read again. I found it very disappointing. It definitely wasn’t my cup of tea, and I doubt I’ll be looking for other books by this author.

I won this book in a Goodreads giveaway. All opinions in this review express my honest and true reactions to reading this book.
